postsData.content:
Board Perspective: The AI Value Shift We Can't Ignore
Just watched a fascinating CNBC segment with remarkable Leslie Picker and the brilliant R "Ray" Wangthat perfectly illustrates why boards need to radically rethink AI investment strategies.

DeepSeek's recent breakthrough is a wake-up call for corporate boards: They've achieved top-10 global AI performance using just ~2,000 NVIDIA chips, at roughly 5% of traditional development costs ($5.6M vs. $100M-$1B).

Three key technology governance implications I'm discussing with my fellow directors and CIOs:

1. The democratization of AI is accelerating faster than most boardroom discussions acknowledge. When a $2.19/million token model rivals $60/million competitors, we need to reassess our technology investment thesis.

2. Resource constraints are driving innovation, not limiting it. DeepSeek's pure reinforcement learning approach proves that capital-efficient AI development is possible â€“ and boards must double down with this insight.

3. Open-source AI is becoming a strategic imperative, not just a technical choice. The transparency and adaptability of these models could fundamentally reshape competitive dynamics in our industries.

For my fellow board directors: We must evolve beyond asking "Should we invest in AI?" to "How do we leverage this democratization of AI capabilities?"

Critical questions for your next board meeting:
- Is our current technology governance framework equipped for rapid AI evolution?
- How are we balancing proprietary vs. open-source AI strategies?
- Are we prepared to capture both operational efficiencies and revenue opportunities from AI?

Thoughts? Would love to hear perspectives from other board members navigating this shift.

comments.commentText: DeepSeek's breakthrough is truly game-changing. As a board member, I've seen firsthand how open-source AI is reshaping our strategy. Your point about moving from "if" to "how" resonates deeply.

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Its crucial for boards to adapt quickly and embrace open-source AI for sustainable growth. Lets lead the change!

8 FREE Prompts! Win job interviewers and land high-paying jobs (FAST!) 

Prepare smarter, speak powerfully, and leave a lasting impact!

Use these proven 8 ChatGPT prompts:


 Prompt 1: Role Success Blueprint

postsData.content:
People who shift from MNCs to Startups usually donâ€™t succeed. Hereâ€™s why

After a longish stint at an MNC

Working for a startup can be an avenue for growth

In title, responsibility and money

Startups also are attracted by the ex-tags in resumes

The larger the company, the more attractive the profile

But this is a recipe for failure

Success in MNCs and success in Startups have two different forumalas

MNCs have robust ecosystems

Your success in an MNC is dependent on 10 other people

Doing their job well

And the system ensures that 8/10 will do that

So the decks are cleared for you to focus on being successful at what youâ€™ve been assigned

Success in a startup is about figuring out what those 10 other people need to do

In order for you to be successful at what youâ€™ve been hired to do

And coaching them and collaborating with them so that you can do your job

Most people are not able to make this shift when they move to Startups

Hence the best startup hiring practise is to hire people

Who have backgrounds and experiences similar to the ecosystem in your startup

The last thing you want is someone learning on your dime

or failing to learn on your dime

comments.commentText:
Honestly, I donâ€™t think this is completely true(I have worked in both a MNC and startups and managed employees as a HR partner where people from different stages of the company have struggled/succeeded ). Both transitions-moving from an MNC to a startup and vice versa come with their own challenges and benefits. When you move from an MNC to a startup, you bring structure, processes, and a larger-scale perspective, which can be super valuable for a startup. But to succeed, youâ€™ve got to be ready to take on ownership beyond your job description and be okay with ambiguity. On the flip side, going from a startup to an MNC can mean adjusting to a slower pace, hierarchical structures, or a more process-heavy environment.

At the end of the day, success in either environment isnâ€™t about where you have worked earlier - itâ€™s about how quickly you can adapt and whether the company has the right support system for people making such transitions. Writing off candidates based on their past experience could mean missing out on some game-changing talent.

I think anyone who has worked their way to top will be able to fit in both the cultures. 

In start up you need to roll up your sleeves and get the work done. Similarly in an MNC at a beginning level you need dirty your hands. So generalization would not be the best way.

So when a start up founder consults me about the senior level recruitment , I always the suggest them to look for what the person did 10 years ago, rather than the current position. If they have grown through ranks...prefer them.

I did a 90-day Twitter (sorry *cough*) - X sprint and these are my results. 


WHY -

I wanted to test another text-first platform because text is such a lower lift and there are many more options to repurpose.


APPROACH -

With the exception of a few one-off thoughts, everything I posted was pre-scheduled.

I spent 10 hours on a Sunday buried in theContent Planner.

***yes Canva has a Content Planner. yes, it is epic and includes multiple socials. yes, it's already included in your subscription. yes, I wantto sponsor me in 2025***

In 10 hours, I created 90 days worth of content.

1 post on Sat & Sun

3-5 posts every morning, every Monday - Friday

So a minimum of 14 posts a week.


ï¸ Y'all I'm booked and busy. I needed to know if Twitter was a place where I could grow a following without having to grow a community. Meaning I spent maybe 4 live hours on the platform during the 90 days resharing, liking, and commenting otherwise I was a ghost.


Spoiler alert: I could not grow a following as a  (or at least not in 90 days).


RESULTS -

357 followers

My very best-performing post got 186 impressions

I didn't pay for an account meaning I don't have access to analytics v Premium, but my rough estimate is -

25-30K total impressions

0 leads

Twitter was not the no-effort lift I hoped for, but 25K + impressions in exchange for 10 hours of work (which I could probably do in 6-7 hours now that I'm more familiar with the platform), isn't a bad trade-off.


Unfortunately, as a result of recent comments and actions made by Elon and other tech oligarchs, I donâ€™t feel comfortable continuing to post content on X.

postsData.content:
The 6 ways "individual action" matters, when we really need "systems change". 

 Green actions aren't all in the same bucket.

â†³ Systems driven: Building a new freeway ï¸

â†³ Individual choice: Growing your own tomatoes 

â†³ The system incentivizes individual choice: Getting a $5,000 EV rebate .

Bucket 1: Government only: Taxes, building permits, banning chemicals, etc.

Bucket 2: Mandated systems created to influence behavior: Building ratings, mandatory carbon disclosure, traffic lights, etc.

Bucket 3: Financial incentives: Rebates for EVs, heat pumps, solar, and cool roofs that require people to individually sign up.

Bucket 4: Individual actions that build to tipping points of systems change:

ï¸ Individuals using resuable grocery bags lead to -> Plastic bag bans.

ï¸ Individuals choosing reusable coffee cups lead to -> Disposable cup surcharges.

 People cycling more leads to -> More bike paths.

Bucket 5: Personal Innovation: Creating an innovative clean energy product, a green wall technology, an electric transport startup, or zero waste training, etc.

Bucket 6: Individual only: Growing your own vegetables, using period undies, personal food choices, planting fruit trees, advocating at work, composting, starting a local group, helping neighbors, etc.

This is no dichotomy or binary of "system" vs "Individual" change.

It's all one system consisting of many systems within systems - an interplay between cause and effect, system and individual.

Behavior design is about looking at the entire system and finding ways to influence large numbers of humans, at scale, to do things differently.

As a behavior or action designer, our job is to design new systems that effectively encourage people to respond in the right way.

Enjoy this? Share and follow andfor daily tips on how to build a movement of change.

postsData.content:
When anger rains, leadership reigns no more

Last week, I sat on a panel, & someone hit me with: â€œWhatâ€™s the single most important leadership skill to learn?â€ Without blinking, I said, â€œ
.â€ The moderator, clearly in the mood for specifics, leaned in: â€œOkay, but which emotion?â€ My answer was swift: â€œ
.â€ & here's why.

Anger is the emotional equivalent of a cracked windshield. It doesnâ€™t shatter your vision entirely but distorts it enough to make bad decisions seem reasonable. Neuroscience shows that when you're angry, the amygdalaâ€”the brain's fight-or-flight centerâ€”hijacks rational thought. This phenomenon is called an amygdala hijack (yes, it's as bad as it sounds)

In these moments, your prefrontal cortexâ€”the part responsible for logic & decision-makingâ€”basically takes a nap. Studies from Harvard suggest that anger impairs your ability to assess risks, communicate effectively, & process information accurately. In short, youâ€™re not the leader they hiredâ€”youâ€™re a toddler with a title.

1. Tunnel vision: Anger narrows your focus, so instead of seeing opportunities, you fixate on the problemâ€”or worse, the person causing it.

2. Ego inflation: Anger convinces you that youâ€™re right, even when youâ€™re very, very wrong. Psychologist Martin Seligman calls this the "rage-blind bias" where you double down on bad decisions because youâ€™re too heated to consider alternatives.

3. Collateral damage: Anger doesnâ€™t just hurt youâ€”it scorches everything around you. UI research found that leaders who express anger regularly reduce team performance by up to 40%. Imagine being the emotional grenade in your own office.

Letâ€™s not sugarcoat it: anger is inevitable. Youâ€™re human, & leadership is stressful. But the goal isnâ€™t to suppress angerâ€”itâ€™s to manage it. Hereâ€™s how:

â€¢ Name it to tame it: Psychologist Daniel Siegel suggests simply labeling your emotions can calm your brain. The next time youâ€™re seething, try saying (to yourself, preferably), â€œIâ€™m feeling angry.â€ This reduces the amygdalaâ€™s grip on your brain.

â€¢ The 6-second rule: Studies show it takes about 6 seconds for the chemicals triggered by anger to dissipate. Count to 6, breathe, orâ€”if necessaryâ€”excuse yourself to scream into a pillow.

â€¢ Question your assumptions: Anger thrives on incomplete narratives. Before reacting, ask: â€œAm I seeing this clearly, or am I just mad?â€ Spoiler: Itâ€™s probably the latter.

â€¢ Channel it wisely: Use anger as a motivator, not a weapon. Let it fuel solutions, not vendettas. Turn â€œIâ€™m furious about this problemâ€ into â€œIâ€™m energized to fix this problemâ€

Anger clouds your vision more than any other emotion, turning molehills into mountains & teammates into enemies. As one wise leader once said, "Anger is like drinking poison & expecting the other person to die." Except in leadership, itâ€™s your team that suffers the most. So put the poison down, take a deep breath, & lead with visionâ€”not venom.

comments.commentText: Emotional regulation is indeed crucial for effective leadership. Recognizing anger and reframing it into actionable insights can transform challenges into growth opportunities for the entire team.

postsData.commentAdded: Powerful insights! Managing anger effectively can transform our leadership approach and strengthen team dynamics. Letâ€™s lead with clarity!

postsData.content:
It's NOT rocket science.

I've built multiple 6-figures ($) in my online business through organic content.

Here's what I've learnt:

1. You Are the Niche

You donâ€™t need to fit into a niche.

â†’ You are the niche.

Your unique mix of experiences, skills, and personality is your competitive advantage.

When you show up as your true self and share your story, youâ€™ll naturally attract the right audience.

Donâ€™t overthink this step.

Just start.

2. Focus on Your Personal Brand

Building trust is the foundation of any successful online business.

And trust comes from showing up consistently.

Use platforms like LinkedIn or Instagram to share valuable insights, lessons learned, or even mistakes youâ€™ve made.

Your audience will value your authenticity.

In a world that will be run by AI agents, your personal brand and being human will be everything.

Your personal brand drives your business.

3. Engage, Donâ€™t Just Publish Content

Think of social media as a two-way conversation.

Engage with your audience.

Respond to comments, ask questions, and listen to what people want.

This helps you activate the platformâ€™s algorithm and the feedback loop helps you refine your offerings.

If you engage with your followers they will feel seen and heard and invest more time in you.

â†’ Together you will build your business.

4. Monetize Through Value

Start small.

Offer something that solves a specific problem; an e-book, a course, or a consultation call.

Once you understand what your audience needs,

you can expand into subscriptions, done-for-you services, courses, memberships, or collaborations.

5. Stay Lean and Profitable

Itâ€™s tempting to chase rapid growth,

but in the early stages  cash flow is more important than scale.

Focus on creating a lean operation that serves your clients well

and keeps expenses low.

Growth will come naturally once youâ€™ve built a solid foundation.

Remember:  Camels are the new unicorns

6. You Donâ€™t Need Complex Strategies and Fancy Tools to Monetize Your Audience

You have indirect access to 5.5 billion people through the internet.

You donâ€™t need fancy tools to start monetizing your audience.

Start with the basics.

Once youâ€™ve established workflows and understand your processes, introduce AI tools to save time and scale.

From generating content ideas to automating customer engagement, AI can help you work smarter, not harder.

The key is to keep it simple at the beginning and scale as you grow.

7. Great Things Take Time

Lastly, donâ€™t rush the process.

Building something sustainable takes time.

Test different ideas,

gather feedback,

and refine your approach as you go.

Focus on showing up authentically, delivering value, and staying consistent.

Over time, youâ€™ll build not just a business,

but a community of people who trust and believe in what you offer.

Hope you found this helpful.

postsData.name:
Jason Vana
Jason Vana
postsData.content:
Prospects consume my content for 1 year before working with me.

Sometimes, it's upwards of 3-4 years.

Here's why â†“

The demand you have to create is proportional to the level of depth you'll have in their company.

My brand strategies go deep.

We touch e-v-e-r-y-t-h-i-n-g in your company:

â†’ offer (we've revamped this for every client)
â†’ marketing
â†’ content
â†’ sales
â†’ pricing
â†’ operations
â†’ service/support
â†’ human resources

I get all up in your business when we work together.

And recommend what you should and should NOT do.

It takes time to build that level of trust.

You aren't going to watch one video and trust me with your company.
Or read one sassy rant and throw money at me.

You'll need to see that I know what I'm doing.

And that can take YEARS.

But if I sold a LinkedIn course.
Or content creation.
Or website design.
Or SEO.

The level of trust is lower.

Because SEO doesn't impact how you hire employees.
Website design doesn't impact your operations.
Content creation only impacts marketing.

And that LinkedIn course?
It impacts the smallest of all slivers in your business.

The deeper the impact, the more trust is needed.

Remember that when trying to generate demand.

The LinkedIn course creators will sell more faster.
Because they don't need to generate much trust.

But if you're getting all up in someone's business?

Demand takes longer to generate.

Be patient.

I'm 5.5 years in.

And I'm reaping clients from content I created 4 years ago.

That's how a brand actually works.

comments.commentText: High impact means longer trust process. When you yield the results, it's also a solid foundation for your business. If you want long term solutions, you'll have to push longer.

Colby Wegter That's the piece most people don't realize.

If you don't want to wait as long, lower your prices. If you're okay with waiting months or years, raise your prices.
Colby Wegter Absolutely Colby! Building trust leads to lasting successâ€”same applies to crafting websites.
